title: Small complex icosidodecahedron
text:
In <a href="geometry">geometry</a>, the small complex icosidodecahedron is a degenerate <a href="uniform%20star%20polyhedron">uniform star polyhedron</a>. Its edges are doubled, making it degenerate. The star has 32 faces (20 <a href="triangle">triangle</a>s and 12 <a href="pentagon">pentagon</a>s), 60 (doubled) edges and 12 vertices and 4 sharing faces. The faces in it are considered as two overlapping edges as topological polyhedron.
A small complex icosidodecahedron can be <a href="Wythoff%20construction">constructed</a> from a number of different <a href="vertex%20figure">vertex figure</a>s.
A very similar figure emerges as a geometrical truncation of the <a href="great%20stellated%20dodecahedron">great stellated dodecahedron</a>, where the pentagram faces become doubly-wound pentagons ({5/2} --> {10/2}), making the internal pentagonal planes, and the three meeting at each vertex become triangles, making the external triangular planes.
As a compound.
The small complex icosidodecahedron can be seen as a <a href="polyhedron%20compound">compound</a> of the <a href="icosahedron">icosahedron</a> {3,5} and the <a href="great%20dodecahedron">great dodecahedron</a> {5,5/2} where all vertices are precise and edges coincide. The small complex icosidodecahedron resembles an icosahedron, because the great dodecahedron is completely contained inside the icosahedron.
Its two-dimensional analogue would be the compound of a regular <a href="pentagon">pentagon</a>, {5}, representing the icosahedron as the "n"-dimensional <a href="pentagonal%20polytope">pentagonal polytope</a>, and regular <a href="pentagram">pentagram</a>, {5/2}, as the "n"-dimensional star. These shapes would share vertices, similarly to how its 3D equivalent shares edges.
